qas.question: How did the Rhine extend watershed southward?
What period did the Rhine capture streams?
Where are the streams the Rhine captured?
What caused the Rhine to extend its watershed northward?
When were the Vosges Mountains captured by the Rhine?
What were the northern Alps flooded by?
What mountain range contains Lake Constance?

context: Through <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b3_0>stream capture<b3_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, the Rhine extended its watershed southward. By the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b4_0>Pliocene<a1_1/> period<b4_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/>, <b6_0>the Rhine<b6_0/> had captured streams down to the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>Vosges Mountains<a2_1/><a2_0/>,<a2_2/> including the Mosel, the Main and the Neckar. The northern Alps were then drained by <b5_0>the Rhone<b5_0/>. By the early Pleistocene period, the Rhine had captured most of its current Alpine watershed from the Rhône, including the Aar. Since that time, the Rhine has added the watershed above Lake Constance (Vorderrhein, Hinterrhein, Alpenrhein; captured from the Rhône), the upper reaches of the Main, beyond Schweinfurt and the <b7_0>Vosges Mountains<b7_0/>, captured from the Meuse, to its watershed.
